prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Criticism—Protection of Confidential Business Information as a Form of Property Would Be Contrary to Public Policy

para.paratext: It has been argued that the government should not protect the right to confidential business information because an individual should not be allowed to maintain a monopoly for a longer time than that set by the limits of patent laws. If a party chooses not to register a patent in return for exclusive use of the idea for the term of the patent, the inventor ought to bear the risk of having his or her idea discovered. It has also been argued that no inventor should have a perpetual monopoly over information as this would be contrary to the interests of the state and would obstruct the proliferation of new ideas. Finally, it is argued that the legal protection of confidential business information would place the owners of that information in a better position than those inventors who choose to register patents.[1]

However, what the laws protect is the unauthorized use of information. Independent inventors are free to discover confidential business information by fair means and thus, the protection of confidential information should in no way inhibit the creation of new information. Furthermore, the registration of patents is often unpredictable when dealing with research in progress and may prove unduly onerous on smaller operations with fewer resources to expend on the registration of patents.

In any event, the creators of confidential business information are not on a better footing than those who have registered patents. Those who have registered patents have an absolute monopoly over the information for the term of the patent, while the creators of confidential business information forever run the risk that a third party will independently discover the same information or will acquire the confidential business information by way of reverse engineering.[2]

On the other hand, there would seem to be reason in principle for allowing the protection of other intellectual property rights such as patent, copyright and trade marks, but not to provide protection for confidential business information, since the protection of confidential business information does not necessarily provide the owner with better protection, but simply different protection than would be obtained by registering a patent.[3]
D. Vaver, “Civil Liability: Trade Secrets in Canada” (1980-81), 5 C.B.L.J. 253 at p. 266.
S. Cheung, “Property Rights and Trade Secrets”, Economic Inquiry, vol. xx (January 1982); Samuel Moore & Co. v. Commissioner of Patents (1979), 110 D.L.R. (3d) 35 at p. 38, [1980] 2 F.C. 350 (C.A.).
